Award.AwardTitle: Planning IUCRC at SDSU Site: Center for Solid-State Green Electric Power Generation and Storage (CEPS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF IUCRC Center for Solid-State Green Electric Power Generation and Storage (CEPS) is based on long-term partnerships between universities, industry, national laboratories, and state and federal institutions. The Center seeks to provide solutions for safe, high efficiency, and eco-friendly sustainable solid-state energy storage. This all-solid-state energy storage technology is important for portable, automotive, space, and military applications. The prospective Center will conduct research to expand the fundamental scientific knowledge related to charge transfer in solid state applications. This research will enable, facilitate, and advance the design, synthesis, and manufacturing of the all-solid-state glass-ceramic materials used for solid-state energy storage. The faculty associated with the Center will also mentor young scientists providing a broad multidisciplinary educational experience.

The prospective Center focuses on advancing understanding of fundamental mechanisms that take place in novel super-fast solid-state glass-ceramic conductors under electric transient conditions and correlation of these mechanisms. New knowledge and scientific contributions to the field of solid-state ionics will be generated through the following: 1) Mechanisms of micro- and nanostructural evolution of novel nano-architectures at atomic scale; 2) Understanding mass and charge transfer mechanisms by in-situ operando studies; 3) Self-charging mechanisms within intrinsically integrated solid-state energy storage multilayer structures involving perovskite solar cells; 4) New miniaturization technology leading to safe, human-friendly, and long-lasting solid-state energy storage systems for medical applications; and 5) Solid-state energy storage integration into green power generation systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A strong CEPS team involving four University Sites has been established. A successful CEPS Planning Grant meeting gathered over 100 participants, among them SD and Rapid City administration, faculty and students from four universities, and industry/national labs/federal agency representatives. Eleven presentations emphasizing the major CEPS thrust areas were made by the faculty from the four universities  on day one. Using the NSF L.I.F.E. format, the level of interest toward each of the 11 presented thrust areas has been identified. The questions submitted by the attendees were discussed during the open panel discussion on Day 2. The closed-door session revealed unanimous CEPS support, as mentioned by the NSF representatives.

CEPS has identified and prioritized several major economy sectors  based on extensive Internet search, participation in battery conferences, phone interviews, communication through LinkedIn, Facebook, and Twitter. . A database of individual contacts including 200+ companies within those sectors was created.  However, the targeting remains relatively broad since almost every economy sector rely on energy storage, and CEPS activities could be attractive for many companies in the U.S. and around the world.

This is in line with the recent statement made by U.S. Energy Secretary D. Brouillette on January 8th 2020 emphasizing that “Energy storage is key to capturing the full value of our diverse energy resources”[1]. The following sectors were identified: (1) Primary sector involving raw materials e.g. lithium, aluminum, rare earth and transition metals for battery manufacturing. Established as a Mining school, SDSMT has strong relationships with some of these companies focused on “energy-critical elements” (ECEs)[2].

However, the companies involved in manufacturing of higher value-added materials and products (secondary sector) were chosen as the CEPS main focus. These are the companies that target materials synthesis, production of battery components, and equipment manufacturing for plasma, aerosol-jet, 3D, or laser deposition as game-changing technologies for battery R&D. Furthermore, tertiary and quaternary/knowledge sectors are also in great need of the next-generation energy storage. Based on over 200 discovery interviews, a large number of companies interested in energy storage has been identified. Fig. 3 represents potential NSF CEPS members from industry, national labs, and federal agencies that have interviewed.

The Planning Grant Meeting was the major outcome of this project. The registration for the CEPS Planning Grant meeting was available on online at www.GreenCEPS.com. Overall, over 100 attendees participated in the Planning Grant Meeting, among them 47 representatives from industry, federal agencies and National labs. A few attendees obtained a permission to access the meeting remotely in real time using Zoom. Significant help in preparation for the Planning Grant Meeting was received from the SDSMT undergraduate students. They were involved in printing out and assembling the folders, preparing badges, and answering the questions from the CEPS meeting attendees.


[1] U.S. Department of Energy Launches Energy Storage Grand Challenge; https://www.energy.gov/eere/amo/articles/us-department-energy-launches-energy-storage-grand-challenge

[2] https://www.aps.org/policy/reports/popa-reports/upload/elementsreport.pdf
